{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3664712,"name":"Enzo","username":"biboSguy_Enzo","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/3be4f8/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-26T00:19:18.941Z","cooked":"

"Recently, I found several teams that use the same motor for both drivetrain traction and for lifting their elevator during the climb. I would like to learn more about this mechanism and understand how it works, along with any tips you can share.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-06-26T00:19:18.941Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":19,"reads":219,"readers_count":218,"score":138.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":503653,"topic_slug":"ftc-single-motor-drive-and-lift","display_username":"Enzo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":75867,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"From Brazil"},"post_url":"/t/ftc-single-motor-drive-and-lift/503653/1","custom_user_title":"From Brazil","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3664737,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-26T01:14:03.457Z","cooked":"

Your search term for the day is:

Power TakeOff

or “PTO”.

It’s a mechanism that allows a power source (like a motor and gearbox) to be used in multiple ways. Could be as simple as a shifting gearbox that, when shifted, runs a different output shaft.

You may need to adjust spelling and capitalization when you look.

Keep in mind that something has to switch the PTO from driving to climbing. In FTC, this is usually done by a servo. So this doesn’t cost one of your precious 8 motors, but it does still cost a servo or two.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-06-26T18:43:26.399Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":144,"readers_count":143,"score":28.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":503653,"topic_slug":"ftc-single-motor-drive-and-lift","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41730,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"engineering mentor FRC 3494 & FTC 11329"},"post_url":"/t/ftc-single-motor-drive-and-lift/503653/3","custom_user_title":"engineering mentor FRC 3494 & FTC 11329","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3666220,"name":"Peyton Yeung","username":"Peyton_Yeung","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peyton_yeung/{size}/4840_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-27T03:11:35.194Z","cooked":"

The most common form I’ve seen in FTC involves some form of gear crashing method of shifting that loads a gear in or out of alignment with a driven gear. This is often done with a servo and a linkage (be sure to be aware the force requirement to keep the gears meshed under load).

This video shows an implementation of a PTO to run the climb off the drive gearbox.

A dog shifter is another method you could use to pull power from one item and apply it to another. This often is tricky to implement in an FTC environment as the dog gear is typically engaged linearly and requires some specialized components.
